title: What song goes “mama told me…”? - Quora

response.answer_text: What song goes “mama told me…”? A good number of songs over different decades contain these words. I remember them from a song in the 1970s. A young man is telling how he felt about a party he attended.  This was written by Randy Newman, the nephew of Academy Award-winning composer Lionel Newman. The song is about a party that left a "bad taste" in the writer's mouth. The drug scene was fairly new to American middle-class youth at that time.Randy Newman explained in a 2017 interview with Rolling Stone: "It's a guy going to a party, and he's a little scared. The first line ("Will you have whiskey with your water or sugar with your tea") was a vague connection to acid. I don't remember being thrown off by that stuff then. If I was that unsophisticated - which is possible - I wouldn't admit it."“And that cigarette you're smoking 'Bout to scare me half to death” is really self-explanatory, isn’t it? I remember I was invited to go to my first concert in St. Louis, MO. to see Ted Nugent and the Amboy Dukes. I had no idea what to expect as I had never heard of the group and had never been to a rock concert before. So Ms. Prim and Proper Teacher filed into this auditorium, the light went down and everyone lit up! All I could think was, “If any of my students are here and see me, I am so fired! The Great Wagaboo* will fly me from the flagpole in the circle drive!! Talk about that cigarette you’re smoking and me being scared to death! Then the curtains opened and out came this guy in, well, a loincloth.  What songs did I hear? Don’t ask me! I was too busy politely avoiding all the lit joints being offered me from the front, back, both sides, somehow up between my knees, and I swear one was dropped in my hair. After an eternity of fending off funny cigs, sugar cubes, pills, and who knows what else, the concert was over. The lights went off — about 30 seconds passed — and the ceiling lights came on. EEEEEEEKKKK!  A solid line of blue was across the stage! I just knew I was going to be in the hoosegow that night and out of a job on Monday.  After that, I swore I would go only to concerts with stick-in-the-mud, small-town, Prim-and-Proper folk like me — if any existed!  Pinterest pictures *my nickname for my Principal Three Dog Night - Songfacts

One of my favorite bands, Three Dog Night! Just how phenomenally popular was Three Dog Night? I find it amazing that their first four albums were released in the span of just 18 months, and yielded 10 Top 40 hits.  At the time of their popularity, I had 3 dogs and my last name was “Knight,” so some friends who knew popular music called me, “Three Dog Knight.” And because I was a huge fan, I thought it was a great nickname! Three Dog Knight, and I loved it. Since the group’s singers all had good lead voices, they switched lead singers from song to song. Following are their fantastic chart toppers: OneTry A Little TendernessEasy To Be HardEli’s ComingCelebrateMama Told Me (Not To Come)Out In The CountryOne Man BandJoy To The WorldLiarAn Old Fashioned Love SongNever Been To SpainThe Family Of ManBlack And WhitePieces Of AprilShambalaLet Me Serenade YouThe Show Must Go OnSure As I’m Sittin’ HerePlay Something Sweet (Brickyard Blues)‘Til The World Ends Three Dog Night – defined “pop anthem” and made Three Dog Night one of the world’s most popular bands. Still today those recordings have endured the fickleness of pop, waves of ’70s nostalgia and the test of time. Here’s my absolute favorite by Three Dog Night.  1969’s “Try A Little Tenderness” was the first, reaching #29. The second, the Nilsson-penned “One,” went to #5 and was the group’s first gold (sales of 1,000,000 copies pre-1976). A cover of the musical Hair’s “Easy To Be Hard” reached #4; Nyro’s “Eli’s Coming” #10, and the infectious “Celebrate” #15. In 1970, Three Dog Night scored its first #1 with its gold rendition of Randy Newman’s “Mama Told Me (Not To Come).” “Out In The Country,” co-written by Williams, peaked at #15. After “One Man Band” hit #19, 1971 opened with “Joy To The World” (written by Axton), a gold single that stayed #1 for six weeks, became the group’s signature song and whose opening line “Jeremiah was a bullfrog” remains a ’70s touchstone. The #7 “Liar” followed. Also that year, the gold “An Old Fashioned Love Song,” written by Williams, was a pop #4 and, from Axton, “Never Been To Spain” a #5. Williams also co-wrote the #12 “The Family Of Man” which charted early the next year. Heard too in 1972 were the gold “Black And White” (#1) as well as “Pieces Of April” (#19), which introduced then-unknown songwriter, Dave Loggins. Two more singles went gold: “Shambala” (#3, 1973) and “The Show Must Go On” (#4, co-written by Leo Sayer, 1974). The remaining Top 40s are “Let Me Serenade You” (#17), Hiatt’s “Sure As I’m Sittin’ Here” (#16), Allen Toussaint’s “Play Something Sweet (Brickyard Blues)” (#33) and the group’s final charter, 1975’s Loggins-penned, “Til The World Ends” (#32). Here’s a Concert performed in 1972.  Three Dog Night disbanded in 1977. Today, Negron, is a solo artist, and Three Dog Night, with Danny Hutton and original bandmate Michael Allsup continue to record and perform for fans who have never forgotten the joy they brought to the world of music. In case you love the band as much as I do, I’m posting a few more videos. I can’t help it!          BIO — Three Dog Night You’re probably thinking that I’m a tiny bit obsessed with Three Dog Knight. And if you are thinking that, you’ve got that right‼️ I❤️3 🐶🐶🐶 …..  __________________________________________________ Sorry to leave on a sad note, but I saw this article for the first time today. Cory Wells dies at 74; cofounder of 1970s band Three Dog Night
